I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the enhancement of 
financial management capacity in Asia and the Pacific, with a focus on: (i) improving the quality 
of financial audits by private and public audit professionals; (ii) supporting the adoption of 
International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS);1 and (iii) developing the financial 
management and audit function capacity of staff in project executing and implementing agencies 
(EAs/IAs) and supreme audit institutions (SAIs) in ADB developing member countries (DMCs).2 
2.  This TA is included as a corporate priority TA in the Work Program and Budget Framework  
for 2018-2020,3  and in the annual work program of ADB’s Procurement, Portfolio and Financial 
Management Department.4 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Many ADB DMCs are challenged in meeting their development goals by weak governance 
and financial management systems. This adversely impacts public confidence in the ability of 
DMC  governments  to  produce  comprehensive  and  credible  financial  information,  which 
constrains their ability to raise adequate capital at reasonable cost and tenor. These weaknesses 
are also found in DMC EAs/IAs and SAIs, where observed deficiencies include: (i) national 
accounting practices that do not follow recognized financial reporting frameworks or standards; 
(ii) poor-quality audits from both public and private auditors, and failure to adhere to relevant 
international auditing standards;5 and (iii) inadequate staff number and capacity. 
4.  A significant proportion of future investment by ADB will be in the public sector of its 
DMCs.6 It  is  imperative  that  financial  management,  reporting,  and  auditing  systems  are 
strengthened to better manage the processes by which investment projects are selected, and to 
ensure subsequent operation and management of infrastructure is undertaken in a transparent 
and responsible manner. 
5.  The TA is directly linked to: (i) the strengthening of governance and institutional capacity, 
which is a key operational priority of ADB’s Strategy 2030;7 and (ii) Sustainable Development 
Goal 16 (Target 16.6), which aims to “develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions 
at all levels”. The TA targets improvements in governance and financial management to create 
an  enabling  environment  for  sustainable  growth,  strengthen  service  delivery,  and  improve 
capacity and standards. The TA will leverage ongoing cooperation with DMCs and support ADB 
policy loans supporting economic reforms. By strengthening financial reporting and auditing in 
DMCs,  the  TA  will  contribute  to  improved  accountability,  institutional  capacity,  and  better 
governance, leading to more efficient use of limited resources and better service delivery. 
                                                
1  IPSAS are a set of generally accepted accounting standards issued by the IPSAS board for use by governments and 
public sector entities in the preparation of their financial statements. These standards are based on International 
Financial Reporting Standards. 
2  SAIs (commonly referred to as an auditor general) carry out the external audit of public sector bodies and are a 
critical financial accountability mechanism in most countries. 
3   ADB. 2017. Work Program and Budget Framework 2018-2020. Philippines.      
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on [day Month year] (to be inserted

5  International Auditing Standards are standards for the performance of audit of financial information, issued by the 
International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board. 
6  The aggregate climate-adjusted infrastructure investment need for Asia and the Pacific is estimated at $26.2 trillion 
from 2016 to 2030, equal to an average annual requirement of $1.7 trillion. 
7  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.

2 
Strengthening EA/IA financial management and SAI audit capacity would also contribute to 
effective implementation of anticorruption measures—sound financial reporting and SAI audit 
quality contribute to the robust management and control of public resources and effective delivery 
of public services. 
6.  Private sector auditing capacity in many parts of Asia and the Pacific is constrained by 
limited resources, poor professional competence, and a lack of or weak regulatory oversight. 
Implementing an auditor quality assurance program would create an enabling environment for 
capacity development of the private sector auditing profession. A robust quality assurance system 
would  enhance  the  adoption  and  implementation  of  international  professional  and  ethical 
standards and reinforce best practices through timely investigation and discipline, and instill public 
confidence. This will contribute to the production of high-quality and reliable audited financial 
statements, which is a critical accountability mechanism. 
7.  SAIs are public sector audit organizations that focus on accountability and transparency 
in the use of public funds. They are uniquely placed to help build and sustain stronger, more 
effective  accountability mechanisms.  SAIs  conduct  many  audits  of  varying types,  including 
financial,  performance,  compliance,  and  other  ad  hoc  audits.  Despite  the  acknowledged 
importance of SAIs for development effectiveness, public sector auditing in many countries is the 
weakest component of public financial management (PFM).8 Strengthening SAIs by building their 
capacity and developing systems and procedures for effective implementation of an audit quality 
management  framework  (AQMF)  will  result  in  better-quality  audits  and  help  improve  PFM 
practices. 
8.  Adoption  by  DMCs  of  IPSAS  and  issuance  of  IPSAS-compliant  audited  financial 
statements would represent a significant achievement. Implementation of IPSAS improves the 
comprehensiveness,  quality,  and  comparability  of  financial  reporting,  while  increasing 
accountability and transparency. In addition, strengthened internal controls and stronger quality 
assurance  mechanisms  will  better  support  government  efforts  to  realize  their  fiscal  goals. 
Increased understanding of financial information contributes to informed decision-making and 
increased accountability in public resource use and asset management. 
9.  Robust financial management capacity on the part of EA/IA staff is critical to improving 
governance, transparency, and accountability with respect to the use of public and donor funds. 
Better understanding of financial reporting and audit requirements would promote better allocation 
and  management  of  public  and  donor  resources,  and  ultimately  strengthen  public  service 
provision by DMCs. 
10.  The TA identifies several DMCs for participation. More may be included in the future in 
response to: (i) a direct request by the respective government; (ii) implementation of ADB policy-
based lending to strengthen governance and PFM; and/or (iii) a strong commitment by in-country 
counterparts to strengthening financial management. 
11.  The TA will build on the following lessons from ADB’s ongoing regional TA:9 (i) private 
auditor  quality  assurance  programs  are  regular,  continuous,  and  long-term,  and  require 
methodological and financial support to sustain momentum and achieve meaningful results; and

(ii) there is a significant demand by EAs/IAs and SAIs for financial reporting and audit capacity 
development.10 ADB’s ongoing TA has enabled Cambodia, Georgia, Nepal, and Samoa to 
establish quality assurance systems that will be implemented over a period of 6 years. The TA 
will continue program support for these DMCs for the next 3 years of the quality assurance system 
implementation cycle. Armenia and the Philippines will be included under the TA to establish and 
implement quality assurance systems.11 
12.  The  TA  will  help  strengthen  governance  and  institutional  capacity  in  DMCs  by: 
(i) continuing beyond the 30 June 2019 closing date the work begun under ADB’s ongoing TA 
(footnote 9) on private audit quality assurance programs in four countries, and extending this work 
to two more DMCs; (ii) addressing IPSAS implementation for Uzbekistan and AQMF for Pakistan 
(these were not included under the ongoing TA);12 and (iii) addressing the need for financial 
management capacity building of EAs/IAs and SAIs.   
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: governance strengthened, and institutional 
capacity and standards improved in participating DMCs’ financial management. The TA will have 
the  following  outcome:  public  and  private  audit  and  accounting  capacity  for  improved 
management of public resources enhanced.13 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
14.  Output 1: Private auditor quality assurance programs implemented. High-quality 
audits reinforce good governance, accountability, participation, predictability, and transparency. 
This enhances the confidence of stakeholders in the credibility of financial reports. The TA will 
continue the implementation of quality assurance systems in Cambodia, Georgia, Nepal, and 
Samoa,  while  designing  and  implementing  quality  assurance  systems  in  Armenia  and  the 
Philippines.  This  will  help  in  the  development  of  capable  and  competent  accountancy 
professionals, promotion of strong professional and ethical standards, enhancement of the quality 
of financial reporting and auditing, and improvement of the quality of audited financial statements 
for  ADB-funded  projects.  Output  1  will  focus  on  Armenia,  Cambodia,  Georgia,  Nepal,  the 
Philippines, and Samoa.14 
15.  Output 2: Uzbekistan International Public Sector Accounting Standards road map 
developed. IPSAS implementation results in increased transparency, which provides a better 
understanding of a country’s financial performance, greater accountability to make informed 
decisions about resource utilization, and improved financial information to support governance, 
management of assets, and decision-making. The TA will support: (i) development of a cash basis

4 
IPSAS implementation road map for Uzbekistan; and (ii) advisory and methodological assistance 
to the Uzbekistan Ministry of Finance until formal adoption of the road map.15 Uzbekistan is 
undertaking important economic reforms that will ensure that future growth is broad-based and 
inclusive. These reforms are supported by an ADB policy-based loan that will finance two 
subprograms to be implemented during 2018–2019.16 IPSAS implementation in Uzbekistan will 
enable better accountability, transparency, and governance of public spending and revenues. 
While developing the road map, the TA will leverage the IPSAS e-learning module developed 
under ongoing TA (footnote 9). 
16.  Output 3: Pakistan audit quality management framework implemented. This will 
contribute to capacity building and system development for AQMF implementation by Pakistan’s 
auditor general (its SAI), and is based on a proposal submitted to ADB by Pakistan’s SAI through 
the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions’ Donor Cooperation Secretariat. 
Pakistan’s SAI adopted the International Standards of Supreme Audit Institutions (ISSAI) and is 
building its staff capacity to comply with the standards. The AQMF is an important tool to address 
institutional reform of Pakistan’s SAI as it moves towards full alignment with ISSAI 40.17 AQMF 
implementation  will  improve  the  quality  of  audits  undertaken  by  Pakistan’s  SAI,  thereby 
strengthening the transparency of public institutions, and the accountability of donor- and DMC-
funded projects. The TA will: (i) train Pakistan SAI staff in principles and procedures of audit 
quality management; (ii) assist in developing an organizational structure, and systems and 
procedures for implementation of AQMF; and (iii) provide advisory support to ensure that quality 
management is mainstreamed across all functions of the organization and all steps of auditing. 
17.  Output 4: Training of EAs/IAs and SAI staff in financial management conducted. The 
capacity of EAs/IAs and/or SAI financial management staff in effective, efficient, and transparent 
accounting and auditing of the use of public funds will be developed through regional training. 
Training under output 4 will be available to all DMCs, but priority will be given to staff of EAs/IAs 
for ADB projects that face financial management issues and challenges. Women will account for 
at least 40% of all EAs/IAs and/or SAI staff trained. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will administer the TA. The Public Financial Management Division of ADB’s PPFD 
will implement the TA in collaboration with regional departments, key professional accounting 
organizations, national audit regulators, and SAIs. Knowledge and resources from ADB’s regional 
departments and ADB’s ongoing TA (footnote 9) will support the TA reform efforts. The TA will 
capture and share public financial management knowledge and best practices with all DMCs 
through public disclosure of relevant documents on ADB’s project website.

21.  Consulting services. The TA will finance  49 person-months of consulting services 
(41 person-months international and 8 person-months national). ADB will engage the consultants 
following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.18 To ensure continuity, it is proposed 
to use single source selection of the existing consultant firm (Institute of Chartered Accountants 
in England and Wales) under the ongoing ADB TA (footnote 9) to continue implementation of the 
quality assurance program in Cambodia, Georgia, Nepal, and Samoa for 3 years.19 This will also 
ensure significant cost savings, as contracting a new consultant entails transition costs, delays 
and slower initial implementation.20 The performance of the consultant proposed for single source 
selection has been satisfactory under the ongoing TA. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding equivalent of $1,100,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Financial Management in Asia and the Pacific, Phase 2, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.
